title: John Lewis hits landlords with fee cut in battle to slash costs
text:
John Lewis has launched an aggressive bid to cut costs by threatening to withhold heating and maintenance fees from landlords.

The loss-making department store chain warned it may refuse to pay 20pc of its service charged at a string of shopping centres, following an increase in the fees.

It could trigger a lawsuit from landlords because John Lewis is contractually obliged to pay the service charge, which is added to its rental bill and covers day-to-day running expenses.

The row comes after John Lewis suffered its first ever half-year loss, and unveiled £100m of cuts as part of a battle to get back in the black.

Richard Cressall, a partner at law firm Gordons, said: “Landlords will have to go to court to recover the service charges, but this is costly and will take time.

“Those landlords who do persevere should succeed, but in this market I think at least some landlords will choose to do a deal rather than fight in court, which must be what John Lewis is hoping for."
description: John Lewis has launched an aggressive bid to cut costs by threatening to withhold heating and maintenance fees from landlords.
